{{Infobox person |name = Susan Alice Buffett |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|07|30}} |birth_place = [[Omaha]], [[Nebraska]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = {{marriage|Allen Greenberg|1983|1995|reason=div.}} |parents = [[Warren Buffett]]
[[Susan Buffett|Susan Thompson]] |relatives = [[Howard Buffett]] {{small|(grandfather)}}
[[Howard Graham Buffett]] {{small|(brother)}}
[[Peter Buffett]] {{small|(brother)}}
[[Howard Warren Buffett]] {{small|(nephew)}}
[[Doris Buffett]] (Aunt) }} '''Susan Alice Buffett''' (born July 30, 1953){{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_pictures/8326586.stm | title = From Warren Buffett's Family Album | date = 26 October 2009 | accessdate = 14 July 2010 | publisher = [[BBC News]]}} is the daughter of [[Warren Buffett]]. She is also an American [[philanthropist]], her charitable work has focused largely on the Sherwood Foundation, formerly known as the Susan A. Buffett Foundation, an organization in [[Omaha]] that provides grants in [[public education]], human services and [[social justice]] in the interest of promoting the [[child welfare|welfare of children]] from lower-income families.{{cite news | url = http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2004/7/30/latest/18236WifeofWa&sec=latest | title = Wife of Warren Buffett, the world's second richest man, dies | date = 30 July 2004 | work = [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | accessdate = 14 July 2010}}{{cite web | url = http://www.sherwoodfoundation.org/about.html | title = About | publisher = The Sherwood Foundation | accessdate = 14 July 2010}}{{cite web | url = http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=2133209&page=1 | title = Exclusive: Buffett Kids React to Dad's Donation | publisher = ''[[Good Morning America]]'' | date = 29 June 2006 | accessdate = 14 July 2010}} She is also on the boards of the [[Buffett Foundation]], The Buffett Early Childhood Institute, and [[Girls, Inc.]]{{cite news | url = http://www.omaha.com/article/20100501/MONEY/705019981/1031 | title = Foundation spending likely to increase along with stock | date = 1 May 2010 | accessdate = 14 July 2010 | last = Jordan | first = Steve | work = [[Omaha World-Herald]]}} According to a 2010 interview with her brother [[Howard Graham Buffett]], Buffett's philanthropic focus has consistently remained on children, education and family issues, but she has also committed to other causes, including [[DATA|Debt, AIDS, Trade, Africa]], a [[non-governmental organization]] dedicated to various improvements in [[Africa]].{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/2005/12/19/bono-buffett-philanthropy-cx_cn_1219autofacescan13.html | title = Bono Stops Over In Buffett Land After Concert | last = Noon | first = Chris | date = 19 December 2005 | accessdate = 14 July 2010 | publisher = [[Forbes]]}} ==Biography== Born in Omaha in 1953, Buffett, commonly called Susie, is the eldest child of [[Warren Buffett]].{{cite web | url = http://www.bcgolfnews.com/2009/01/despite-the-fact-that-his | title = Warren Buffett -- Playing Business Like Tiger Plays Golf | date = January 2009 | accessdate = 14 July 2010 | last = de Waal | first = Mandy | publisher = BC Golf News}}{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/01/business/01buffett.html?_r=2 | title = How Does Warren Buffett Get Married? Frugally, It Turns Out | date = 1 September 2006 | accessdate = 14 July 2010 | work = [[New York Times]] | last = Bailey | first = Jeff |author2=Eric Dash }} She studied at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln, where she was majoring in home economics and at the University of California, Irvine, where she was majoring in social ecology.https://books.google.ee/books?id=wXU4gfkIYjQC&pg=PT106&lpg=PT106&dq=susan+alice+buffett+University+of+California+criminal&source=bl&ots=y_8--HErLM&sig=S2davnB42SuMu5RnEZlcvEPz1kI&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWxJu58pjXAhXmO5oKHT9nCV0Q6AEISjAI#v=onepage&q=susan%20alice%20buffett%20University%20of%20California%20criminal&f=false The Empress Has No Clothes: Conquering Self-Doubt to Embrace Success. Joyce M. Roché, Alexander Kopelman Her parents separated in the late 1970s (though they remained married until her mother's death in 2004). Despite his wealth, Warren Buffett encouraged his children to be financially independent; Susan Buffett recalled in 2006 that in spite of her father's generosity, he once refused her a personal loan of $41,000 to expand her kitchen. Her foundation, however, was funded primarily by $1 billion in shares from her father, Warren Buffett.{{Cite web|url=http://www.minyanville.com/special-features/articles/Susan-Alice-Buffett-warren-buffett-business/8/31/2010/id/29773|title=The Kids of Business Icons: Susan Alice Buffett|website=Minyanville|access-date=2018-11-28}} In 1983, Buffett wed Allen Greenberg, a lawyer for [[Public Citizen]], whom she had met in Washington.{{cite journal | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/02/business/02buffettkids.html?pagewanted=all | title = Buffett Children Emerge as a Force in Charity | date = 2 July 2006 | journal = [[New York Times]] | accessdate = 15 May 2013}} The couple divorced in 1995.{{cite journal | url = http://www.businessweek.com/archives/1999/b3652114.arc.htm | title = The Art of Giving--When Your Resources Are Vast | date = 25 October 1999 | journal = [[Businessweek]] | accessdate = 14 July 2010}} In 1987, Greenberg became the first director of the Buffett Foundation, a title he retained after the couple's divorce. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Buffett Family}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buffett, Susan Alice}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Buffett family|Susan Alice Buffett]] [[Category:People from Omaha, Nebraska]]

{{Infobox person | name = Walter A. Haas Sr. | image = | caption = | birth_date = May 11, 1889 | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | birth_name = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1979|12|7|1889|5|11}} | death_place = San Francisco, California | residence = | nationality = United States | education = B.S. [[UC Berkeley|University of California-Berkeley]] | occupation = businessman | known_for = President of [[Levi Strauss & Co]]. | networth = | spouse = Elise Stern | parents = Fanny Koshland
[[Abraham Haas]] | children = [[Rhoda Haas Goldman]]
[[Peter E. Haas]]
[[Walter A. Haas Jr.]] | family = [[John D. Goldman]] (grandson)
[[Douglas E. Goldman]] (grandson)
[[Peter E. Haas Jr.]] (grandson)
[[Bob Haas]] (grandson)
[[Simon Koshland]] (grandfather) | website = }} '''Walter A. Haas Sr.''' (May 11, 1889 – December 7, 1979), son of the founder of Hellman-Haas Grocery (which became [[Smart & Final]]), was a former president and chairman of [[Levi Strauss & Co]]. Haas was credited with saving the once struggling company. ==Early life and education== Haas was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family, one of four children of [[Abraham Haas]] and Fanny Koshland.[http://www.jmaw.org/abraham-haas-purveyer-of-food-wholesale-retail/ Jewish Museum of the American West: "Abraham Haas: Purveyer of Food Stuffs, Wholesale & Retail, Part 1, Los Angeles"] retrieved April 21, 2014 His father was an immigrant from [[Bavaria]] who founded the Hellman, Hass and Company which eventually became the [[Smart & Final]] grocery store chain. His mother was the daughter of [[Simon Koshland]], one of the most successful wool merchants in [[San Francisco]].[http://www.jmaw.org/abraham-hass-pioneer-entrepreneur-part-2-san-francisco-years/ Jewish Museum of the American West: "Abraham Haas: Purveyer of Food Stuffs, Wholesale & Retail, Part 2, Los Angeles"] retrieved April 21, 2014 His siblings were Charles, Ruth (1891), and Eleanor (1900).[http://www.magnes.org/collections/archives/western-jewish-americana/haas-abraham-correspondence-1885-1886 The Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life: "Berkeley Haas (Abraham) correspondence, 1885–1886"] | The Bancroft Library | University of California | retrieved April 21, 2014 In 1910, Haas graduated with a [[Bachelor of Science|BS]] degree from the [[UC Berkeley|University of California, Berkeley]] College of Commerce.[http://haas.berkeley.edu/haas/about/WHaas.html University of California Berkeley website: About Walter Haas] retrieved March 27, 2013 Haas served in the U.S. Army Field Artillery during [[World War I]]. ==Career== Upon his return to the United States in 1919, he worked at the Levi Strauss & Company, then a small drygoods wholesaler and maker of work clothing, owned by the family of his wife. In 1928, he became president and served in that position until 1955; thereafter, he served as chairman until 1970 and remained active in company affairs until his death in 1979. Haas' tenure and dedication at Levi Strauss – along with that of his business partner and brother-in-law [[Daniel E. Koshland Sr.]], father of physicist [[Daniel E. Koshland Jr.]][http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/33009/daniel-koshland-biologist-and-philanthropist-dies-at-87/ JWeekly: "Daniel Koshland, biologist and philanthropist, dies at 87" by joe eskenazi] July 27, 2007 – is widely credited with saving the company leading it through the [[Great Depression]], racial integration at its factories, the global popularization of the Levi brand, and the creation of the Levi Strauss Foundation.[http://bkfellowships.org/daniel-e-koshland-sr/ Butler Koshland Fellopshops: "Daniel E. Koshland Sr. 1892–1979"] retrieved march 27, 2013 ==Politics and philanthropy== A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he was an alternate delegate to the [[1952 Republican National Convention]]. He was [[Jewish]], and served as president of the San Francisco Jewish Welfare Federation. ==Personal life== In 1914, Haas married Elise Stern, daughter of Sigmund Stern, the son of [[David Stern (businessman)|David Stern]] and the nephew of [[Levi Strauss]][https://archive.org/stream/appreciatquality00haasrich/appreciatquality00haasrich_djvu.txt Regional Oral History Office University of California – The Bancroft Library Berkeley, California – California Jewish Community Series: "Elise Stern Haas – The Appreciation of Quality] An Interview Conducted by Harriet Nathan in 1972 (Strauss had died unmarried and without children and deeded his company to his four nephews).[http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/1698/levi-s-exec-walter-a-haas-jr-recalled-for-generosity/ JWeekly: "Levi’s exec Walter A. Haas Jr. recalled for generosity" by Natalie Weinstein] September 29, 1995 Haas had three children: [[Rhoda Haas Goldman]], [[Peter E. Haas]], and [[Walter A. Haas Jr.]][http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/THE-HAAS-LEGACY-How-one-family-s-generosity-and-2583444.php#page-4 San Francisco Gate: "The Haas Legacy / How one family's generosity and commitment to civic life are transforming the Bay Area" by Julian Guthrie] July 1, 2007 In 1989, the [[UC Berkeley|University of California, Berkeley]] Regents voted to rename the business school the [[Haas School of Business]] in his honor, after a large gift from the Haas family. ==References== * ''Who's Who in America 1964'' {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haas, Walter A.}} [[Category:1889 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Businesspeople from California]] [[Category:Haas School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Haas family]] [[Category:Businesspeople from the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Levi Strauss & Co. people]]
